CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (exhaustion of domestic remedies);No violation of Art. 14+P1-1;No violation of Art. 8

TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . She was the partner of ORG ( ORG ) , a farmer whom she married in a religious ceremony in DATE and with whom she had CARDINAL children . PERSON died on DATE . The applicant stated that on that date , while she and her partner had been making preparations for an official marriage ceremony , PERSON had died following an illness .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought proceedings before ORG on her own behalf and on behalf of her daughter PERSON seeking rectification of the entry concerning her in the civil status register . She requested that her religious marriage to PERSON be recognised and that her daughter be entered in the register as the deceased 's daughter .

CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG refused the applicant 's request concerning her religious marriage but granted the request for Emine to be entered in the register as ORG 's daughter . As no appeal was lodged , the judgment became final .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant requested the NORP retirement pension fund ( “ ORG ” ) to award her and her daughter PERSON a survivor 's pension and health insurance cover on the basis of her late partner 's entitlement . The fund refused the request .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to ORG to have that decision set aside . On DATE the latter decided that it had no jurisdiction ratione loci and that the case should be heard by ORG .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG , in a ruling based on the judgment of ORG , found that the applicant 's marriage to ORG had not been validated . Accordingly , since the marriage was not legally recognised , the applicant could not be subrogated to the deceased 's rights . However , the court set aside the retirement fund 's decision in so far as it related to Emine and granted her the right to claim a pension and health insurance cover on the basis of her deceased father 's entitlement .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed on points of law to ORG . She argued that the extract from the civil status register stated that she was the wife of PERSON , who was registered in the village of PERSON . She explained that in DATE she had married PERSON in accordance with custom and practice . The couple had had CARDINAL children . The first CARDINAL children had been entered in the civil status register in DATE under their father 's name , while the last child , Emine , born in DATE , had been entered under her mother 's name in DATE . The applicant asserted that , unlike her CARDINAL children , she had been unable to claim a pension or health insurance cover based on her deceased partner 's entitlement .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , served on the applicant on DATE , ORG upheld the impugned judgment .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Civil Code provides :
“ A man and a woman who wish to contract a marriage must apply together to the civil status registrar in the place of residence of either CARDINAL of them .

The civil status registrar [ who is to perform the ceremony ] shall be the mayor in the case of a municipality , or the official whom he or she has designated for the purpose , or the muhtar in the case of a village . ”
CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL to CARDINAL of the Civil Code lay down the substantive and formal conditions governing the solemnisation of marriage between men and women .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code reads as follows :
“ At the close of the [ civil ] marriage ceremony the official shall issue the couple with a family record book .
No religious ceremony may be performed without the family record book being produced .
The validity of the [ civil ] marriage is not linked to the performance of a religious ceremony . ”

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Civil Code concerning maintenance payments provides that maintenance in the form of an allowance or periodic payments ceases to be due when the recipient remarries or CARDINAL of the CARDINAL parties dies , or if the recipient is living in a de facto marital relationship outside marriage , is no longer in financial need or has an immoral lifestyle .
CARDINAL . The sixth paragraph of LAW reads as follows :

“ Any person who solemnises a religious marriage without having seen the document certifying that a marriage ceremony was performed in accordance with the law shall be liable to a term of imprisonment of DATE . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Obligations concerns the determination of compensation awards depending on the circumstances and the seriousness of the fault . Article CARDINAL of the Code deals with reductions in compensation awards . Article CARDINAL concerns awards for damages following a death : persons deprived of financial support as the result of a death must receive compensation for loss of income .

CARDINAL . The aim of this PERSON is to safeguard women 's social , economic , cultural and political rights and to combat all forms of discrimination against women and improve their level of educational attainment .

As its title indicates , this PERSON ( repealed on DATE ) dealt with the recording in the civil status register under the father or mother 's name of children born within or outside civil marriage and with the regularisation of the situation of children whose parents had not contracted a civil marriage . The new Civil Code , which entered into force on DATE , no longer distinguishes between children born within and outside marriage .

CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON ) , ORG of ORG set aside a first - instance judgment awarding compensation to a woman living in a religious marriage following the death of her partner in a work - related accident . After reiterating that marriage was a legal institution , that a religious union CARDINAL persons of opposite sex could not be recognised as a marriage and that section CARDINAL(c ) and ( b ) of LAW ( Law no . The court held that in the absence of legislation on the subject , the social security agency could require the woman in question to repay the sums wrongly paid to her after her partner 's death .

CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON DATE ) , on the basis of LAW , ORG of ORG set aside a judgment of the lower court on the ground that a former husband was no longer required to pay maintenance to his ex - wife since the latter was living in a de facto marital relationship with another man , albeit without a marriage certificate , and the couple had a child together .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ( E. CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON ) ORG overturned a criminal court ruling acquitting an imam who had performed a religious marriage ceremony without first checking the document proving that a civil marriage had taken place in accordance with the law .

In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( PERSON , PERSON ) ORG of the plenary ORG ( PERSON ) upheld a first - instance judgment , thereby overturning the judgment of ORG , on the ground that the children and surviving partner from a religious marriage should be awarded compensation after their father and partner was accidentally killed ( by police bullets fired on the fringes of a demonstration ) . ORG observed that the action had been brought by the surviving partner on her own behalf and that of her children , that CARDINAL children had been born of the relationship , resulting from a religious marriage , and that following the man 's death , the children and their mother had been deprived of his financial support ( destekten yoksun kalma tazminatı ) . It pointed out that , while domestic law did not afford protection to or validate such a union , the couple had had children together whose births had been recorded under the parents ' names in the civil status register and the deceased had supported the family financially . Accordingly , it awarded compensation to the children and their mother on account of the man 's death .

CARDINAL . As cohabitation on the basis of religious marriage is a social reality , the courts apply CARDINAL principles of civil liability in awarding compensation to women whose partner in a religious marriage has died :
( a ) compensation for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage ( maddi ve manevi tazminat ) on the basis of ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of Obligations ;
( b ) compensation for loss of financial support ( destekten yoksun kalma tazminatı ) following a death , on the basis of LAW .

CARDINAL . In the specific context of LAW , the legislation refers to couples living together as de facto man and wife without having contracted a civil marriage . In practice , this means religious marriage , and there is no requirement to continue paying maintenance to the other party in the situations contemplated ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . However , ORG does not award the CARDINAL types of compensation referred to in the previous paragraph in the case of same - sex or adulterous relationships , which are deemed to run counter to morals ( see , for example , the judgment of ORG of ORG of DATE ( E. CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON ) ) .

CARDINAL . The legislature does not recognise any form of opposite - sex or samesex cohabitation or union other than civil marriage . The domestic courts interpret the law very strictly . The fact that the general principles articulated in LAW and LAW are applied can not be viewed as tacit or de facto recognition of religious marriage . Although the domestic courts award surviving partners compensation on the basis of general principles of civil liability DATE which can not be equated with the principles governing social security or civil marriage – they never grant them survivor 's pensions or social security benefits based on the deceased partner 's entitlement .

CARDINAL . Under NORP law , a religious marriage requires the presence of CARDINAL male witnesses ( or CARDINAL man and QUANTITY women ) . The marriage is solemnised simply by the couple exchanging vows in the presence of the witnesses , without the need for a cleric ( imam or equivalent ) to be present or for an official document to be drawn up . Under the NORP empire , following a decision taken by the supreme NORP religious authority , the Sheikh - ul - Islam , the presence of an imam or a kadı ( judge ) became compulsory for all marriage ceremonies , on pain of penalties . This practice became widely established , and nowadays the presence of an imam is required . NORP marriages also include a pecuniary element in the form of a dowry ( mahr ) .

CARDINAL . NORP law , save in some specific circumstances ( for instance , the death of the husband ) , recognises repudiation ( talâk ) as the sole means of dissolving a marriage . This is a unilateral act on the part of the husband , who dismisses his wife and thereby severs the marital bond . It entails the husband explicitly repudiating his wife by saying the required form of words CARDINAL times to her ( for example : “ I repudiate you ” or “ You are repudiated ” ) .

CARDINAL . GPE was founded on a secular basis . Before and after the proclamation of the Republic on DATE , the public and religious spheres were separated through a series of revolutionary reforms : the abolition of the caliphate on DATE ; the repeal of the constitutional provision declaring ORG the religion of the ORG on DATE ; and , lastly , on DATE , an amendment to the LAW according constitutional status to the principle of secularism ( see LAW . The principle of secularism was inspired by developments in NORP society in the period DATE and the proclamation of GPE see PERSON v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALXI ) .

CARDINAL . One of the major achievements of LAW was the institution of compulsory monogamous civil marriage between men and women , requiring religious marriages to be preceded by a civil ceremony . The new LAW , which entered into force on DATE , does not cover any forms of cohabitation other than marriage . The national parliament chose not to enact legislation in this sphere .

CARDINAL . According to ORG ( Diyanet İşleri Başkanlığı ) , imams , who are appointed by the ORG , are expressly required to verify that the future husband and wife have been married by a civil status registrar . The “ religious ” ceremony before an imam appointed by the ORG is a mere formality which entails little solemnity . The civil marriage takes precedence over the religious marriage .
